2.00.text:
>>Ben Fried: I'm Ben. I work in Corp Eng,
but this is Steven Levy, the author of--

10.10.text:
>>Ben Fried: the author of "In the Plex: How
Google Thinks, Works, and Shapes Our Lives."

15.76.text:
Let me read you the biographical sketch of
Steven that appears at the end of the book.

21.03.text:
You're more handsome in person than you are
in the picture.

26.51.text:
>>Steven Levy: That's a good photographer,
there.

27.51.text:
>>Ben Fried: It is a good photographer, but
life has been kind to you as well. So--

31.84.text:
Steven Levy--. That was not insulting. That
was meant in the most complimentary terms.

37.18.text: >>Steven Levy: I didn't take it that way.

39.18.text:
[reads passage]
"Steven Levy has covered Google for more than

40.26.text:
a decade. First at Newsweek, where he was
Senior Editor and Chief Technology Writer,

43.90.text:
and now at Wired where he is Senior Writer.
He's also written about Apple, "Insanely Great,"

48.43.text:
and "The Perfect Thing," and is the author
of the classic book, "Hackers: Heroes of the

52.36.text:
Computer Revolution." He lives in New York
with his wife and son."

56.72.text:
So, I do have to add, on a personal note,
you've heard me say this before, I think.

60.04.text:
But the reason I am here today, like at Google
doing my thing, is because I read this book

65.60.text:
in the year between high school, the summer
between high school and college.

70.52.text:
And it changed my life and gave me a sense
of direction and what I wanted to be. And

77.67.text:
so, I reread it every--. The first time I
found out I was gonna meet Steven, I brought

80.92.text:
it with me to show him--I still have the first
edition--how much it means. He was graceful

85.71.text:
enough to sign it. Gracious enough to sign
it. But it was--.

87.99.text:
That's why I'm here. Anyways, so I think the
thing for us to do is open it up to questions.

97.10.text:
Although, I guess by way of introduction,
you did a lot of interviews for this book,

104.61.text:
>>Steven Levy: Lemme talk, maybe I should
talk about how I went into this book--

107.81.text:
>>Steven Levy: and got this. So I've been
covering Google for quite a while. The first

111.65.text:
time I actually went to Google was in 1999.
I had seen the search engine, I think, probably

118.51.text:
it was around the end of 1998. So, I know
I mentioned it in a story in February 1999.

126.41.text:
And for a while, Google had a little newsletter
they sent out about their news hits. And in

133.50.text:
the very first one that was sent out, they
mentioned that little mention I did in Newsweek.

139.98.text:
But I realized at a certain point during 1999,
this wasn't just a cool product. This was

146.65.text:
something that was transformative. And besides
the product being worth seeing, the company

153.71.text: itself was something I really should know.

156.98.text:
So I called up the head of PR at the time,
who I had known 'cause she had worked at Apple,

161.51.text:
Cindy McCaffrey, and said, "I really wanna
meet these guys." And she said, "Next time

165.93.text:
you're out, come by." And I did that. And
it was October of 1999. I know it was October

172.15.text:
because when I got there, and it was in the
original Googleplex on Bay Shore, everyone

180.60.text:
It was almost Halloween. And Larry was dressed
as a Viking. He had a big furry vest--

186.16.text:
a hat with big horns out of it. And Sergey
was dressed like a cow.

190.58.text:
And he had these disgusting udders coming
out of his chest.

194.37.text:
So the Viking and the cow took me into a room
and explained Page Rank to me. And --

198.60.text:
So I knew that was something different. So
I kept covering Google and I did a cover story

203.53.text:
and other big stories for Newsweek. And always
thought that it would be great to write a

208.06.text:
book about Google. But I know there were a
couple books out around the IPO period and

213.66.text: they did a pretty good job.

215.22.text:
And I wondered, "How do I do this?" And then,
in the summer of 2007, I took a trip with

222.55.text:
some of the APMs at Google. Do you all know
what the APM is? Yeah, yeah, you all know,

227.83.text:
right. And so, there's this trip that Marissa
takes the APMs on, the international trip.

234.02.text:
And in this case, we literally went around
the world.

236.93.text:
We started in San Francisco, went to Tokyo,
Beijing, Bangalore, and Tel Aviv. And for

243.55.text:
16 days, I was 24/7 with these great, young
people--the young leaders of Google, the future.

252.41.text:
And being immersed among them was fascinating
to me. I realized there was a dimension of

259.37.text:
Google, which I have never seen portrayed
publicly. There's something else was going

265.29.text:
It was a generational thing. It was a thing
about how people who really understand the

271.38.text:
internet make the use of it and bring it to
all of us. And it's something about the unique

277.89.text:
ambitions and goals and struggles of this
company.

282.08.text:
So I thought, "Wouldn't it be interesting
if I could do a whole book from that inside

287.81.text:
perspective and as much as possible, learn
firsthand in a deep way, what's going on here

296.34.text: at Google for the areas that interest me most."

300.53.text:
And they're broken up in chapters. It's amazing
how closely these chapters represent the outline

308.05.text:
that I did when I was first pitching the book.
And the people in charge of communications,

313.87.text:
then Elliot Schrage, was Head of Communications,
he told me then if I agreed to let Google

320.80.text:
check everything, give Google approval of
everything, he’d give me a badge. I didn't

327.54.text:
And but it went up to LSE, which is one of
many acronyms I've learned—Larry and Sergey,

338.05.text:
and Eric. And they signed off on it. And I
started seriously in June 2008, just about

344.81.text:
the same time I began at Wired, which I left
Newsweek that spring to go full-time at Wired.

353.35.text:
And I was able to talk to pretty much anyone
I wanted. That was the best part there. And

359.50.text:
I could say, "Steve , here's an interesting
person. Could I talk to this person?" Or Karen

365.79.text:
Wickre, who was my shepherd there, would say,
"Here's a really interesting person for you

369.96.text:
to talk to." And she would put me together
with like George Salah, who was a head of

376.96.text:
>>Steven Levy: And he was the guy who Google
hired. There were a number of hires early

381.10.text:
in Google who were the kind of people a small
start-up had no business hiring, like a facilities

386.35.text: guy when they had like ten people, right?

390.52.text:
And he found the places there. And one of
my favorite things that he said to me was

395.52.text:
that "Larry smells things that other people
can't smell." And he was going through and

400.42.text:
they were redoing Building 43 and Larry was
very sensitive to non-organic things in there

406.54.text:
or something. But he explained to me the design
philosophy behind Google's buildings and things

412.99.text:
And of course, I really wanted to spend a
lot of time with people in Search and Ads,

416.92.text:
and get an understanding of how those things
went, because to me, these are characters

422.76.text:
as much as the people. The leaders are characters.
And learning about how Search works and Ads

429.13.text:
work, you learn a lot about Google's values
and their approach and how they view the world

433.46.text: and how they view the internet.

435.07.text:
So with that access, I was able to do this
book. Otherwise, it was a non-starter there.

444.72.text:
>>Ben Fried: So it sounds like an unprecedented
level of access. What was kind of the most

448.51.text:
surprising or interesting thing that you learned,
or unexpected?

451.94.text:
>>Steven Levy: Well, there were a lot. You
go into it saying, "I wanna learn stuff."

456.09.text:
Right? And one surprising thing was everyone
talks about the chaos at Google. And even

463.34.text:
leaders evoke it. And they say, "Well, it's
a creative chaos." Or, "We thrive on disorganization,"

473.36.text:
And indeed, one engine of that chaos or disorganization,
whatever you wanna call it, was the Montessori

481.46.text:
training of Larry and Sergey. I think it was
Marissa who said to me, "You can't understand

487.07.text:
Google unless you know that Larry and Sergey
both went to Montessori." And I asked both

493.72.text:
And they -- both of them acknowledge that
had something to do with their outlook and

497.35.text:
the way they still operate in the company.
And I've noticed certainly figures out in

502.83.text:
the way that they’re perapatric. They just
kind of go around the company. I think Larry

506.60.text:
is a little bit--. Now that he's the CEO,
may not have the freedom that he and Sergey

512.73.text:
had been enjoying to pretty much go anywhere
they wanted at any time.

516.23.text:
But that was part of it. But also, on the
other hand, Google has a lot of internal structures

525.42.text:
to monitor people. Now, I had never heard
of OKRs [Ben Fried laughs] before I went in

530.97.text:
this book. And actually, I was quite surprised
considering the degree to which it's part

535.87.text:
of Google culture that it had never been written
about.

539.30.text:
Just Google "OKRs" in Google, you get very,
very little. And that's surprising because

543.81.text:
you folks know it's a big deal here. And people
talk about their OKRs. And there's a whole

549.63.text:
formal way you deal with OKRs and there's
a sort of informal scuttlebutt on OKRs. Right?

554.89.text:
You don't want to make your OKRs everyyear
because then you're sandbagging it, right?

559.70.text:
And so, for people like us who are YouTubing
this, they're saying, "What's an OKR?"

565.31.text:
That stands for Objective and Key Results.
And it's something that John Doerr actually

569.57.text:
first suggested when Google was very small,
that they implement. Andy Grove originally

576.51.text:
thought of the idea. But Google embraced it
like no other company. And as you know, there's

583.73.text:
quarterly OKR's, and there's yearly and sometimes
division or even the whole company will have

589.58.text:
And you think about it, it's not that surprising
'cause it's measurable. And Googlers love

593.81.text:
to measure things. They love data. And they
love to test and see if the data works. But

598.93.text:
it was fascinating to me to see that and the
peer reviews and other things, that there's

602.89.text:
all these internal structures that show that
Google is, in a sense, kind of organized.

609.17.text:
>>Ben Fried: Should we take questions from
the audience? I don't know if people have

612.89.text:
a lot of questions, if they've read the book.
I could go on asking you questions.

616.87.text:
>>Ben Fried: There's a lot of people here.
I'm wondering if there's--.

617.89.text:
>>Steven Levy: Well maybe folks can come up
to the mic--

620.15.text:
>>Ben Fried: Come up to the mic if you have
a question. Does anyone have a question?

623.46.text: >>Steven Levy: and maybe we could talk.

624.46.text:
>>Ben Fried: Otherwise, I'll make them up.
So I advise you to come up to the mic. And

626.00.text:
while you're thinking of coming up to the
mic, I've been asked to remind you all that

631.56.text:
Steven has had an unprecedented level of access
to the company, but he's still a member of

638.05.text:
And so questions, questions that might perhaps
unwittingly reveal things we do not want revealed

645.97.text:
>>Steven Levy: I do have to tell you that
it was, it was an interesting effect going

649.10.text:
on there. Because as part of the ground rules
of the book, I was allowed to see stuff that

656.19.text:
members of the press could not see. There
was an overall NDA to the book itself where

664.44.text:
anything I gathered during the course of my
research was understood that it was gonna

668.85.text: be embargoed until the book came out.

671.28.text:
And people at Google knew when the book was
coming out. So I could then watch the development

678.62.text:
of certain products. The other thing that
was part of it was that if a product was not

683.38.text:
going to be out by the time my book came out,
I wouldn't be able to write about it. And

687.94.text:
there's one thing in particular--I won't even
say what it is--

692.22.text:
That, that it could not be in my book. And
it was disappointing to me and probably even

697.71.text:
more disappointing to the people who still
haven't finished the product--

701.84.text: >>Ben Fried: I wonder what that could be.

706.89.text:
>>Steven Levy: I'm not gonna give a clue.
But actually, there was a sort of a loophole

712.06.text:
to that. If both sides agreed that we could
go early with it, we could. And we did that

717.37.text:
with Chrome, which I knew about well in advance--the
browser. And we were able to crash a story

723.79.text: for Wired in a short period of time.

727.01.text:
>>Steven Levy: Which worked out really, really
well to everyone's benefit there.

729.29.text:
>>Ben Fried: What was the thing that was hardest
to keep your tongue bit about, right? Of all

733.27.text:
the two plus years, two and a half. '08 to
'11, that's three years really almost. What

738.28.text:
was the thing that you knew was coming that
was hardest to bite your tongue about or not

742.95.text:
to try to publish or tell friends about or
something?

745.25.text:
>>Ben Fried: You're in the job of sharing
information, not hiding it, right?

748.60.text:
>>Steven Levy: I think it wasn't one thing
in particular, but just the idea that there

752.08.text:
was so much good stuff coming out from the
interviews. And I think, I guess the point

755.77.text:
I wanted to make from your previous thing
was people knew that I was in some areas where

761.75.text:
a reporter's not supposed to be. But sometimes
they assumed I was in other areas where--

772.72.text:
>>Steven Levy: And so, what they would say
is, [beeping noises] "Oh, so you know about

776.87.text:
Chrome." They figured, "You know about Chrome,
so I guess you know about X, Y, or Z." And

783.78.text:
they'll say, "Well, lemme tell you, in the
SkunkWorks project the other day blah, blah,

787.36.text:
blah, blah." [Ben Fried laughs.] And I'd say,
"Hmm, OK."

792.68.text:
But I guess even more than that, because I
mentioned LSE before. There's this whole list

797.42.text:
of acronyms. It's sort of like the government
in a sense that there's acronyms.

801.93.text: And the whole little language of Google, right?

806.23.text:
>>Steven Levy: You say [thump noise] just
referring, "I sold 443 and went to the GPA

812.83.text:
and then checked with the OC." And everyone--.
[Ben Fried laughs.] So, the fact that I could

820.30.text:
speak to Googlers in that language created
a comfort zone that pretty quickly, within

826.59.text:
an interview, we reached a level of candor
I think.

831.52.text:
And I think that this was part of the plan.
It wasn't putting one over on Google. I think

836.01.text:
part of the idea of my doing this, this is,
was the sense that if Google were transparent,

841.15.text:
at least to this writer, people would learn
about it. And what they'd learn would be something

846.10.text:
that might make Google less threatening as
it became a big company.

850.38.text:
So, it's not a question that I'm putting one
over on you folks, but sunlight accrues to

857.58.text:
the benefit of Google because it's a company.
And I can say pretty confidently, people here

864.34.text:
believe that they're doing the right thing,
that it's a company very much based on moral

870.10.text:
And actually, there's a big, big thread in
my book about how these moral principles play

875.75.text:
out and how Google tries, and sometimes struggles,
to uphold those moral principles--being a

882.62.text:
big company, dealing in areas like China.
And to me it's a great drama. And I think

890.62.text:
it's terrific that these still matter at Google.
And I think they do.

896.20.text:
>>MALE AUDIENCE MEMBER #1: Steve thanks for
coming here. Now that the book's out and people

900.53.text:
like Charlie Rose are quizzing you about it,
what's the most common, or what are the most

904.64.text:
common things that you get about, "Wow. I
did not know about that about Google," or,

909.27.text:
"Wow. I never would have guessed that about
Google."

911.63.text:
>>Steven Levy: Well, people talk about a couple
things. One would be, and the book is just

916.33.text:
getting out now. Literally yesterday was the
publication day. So, people have just been

920.39.text:
seeing it for a week. There was an article
in the New York Times that came out that sort

923.93.text:
of summarized some things, but I don't think
we get the whole context of even the things

928.34.text:
that they mentioned, they seized on the China
thing.

931.58.text:
And really, there's new information. There's
a lot in that China section. And I was really

937.63.text:
glad that I spent a lot of time on that. I
knew I wanted to do a very big internal, international

942.77.text:
component to the book. In general, reporters
I think in the United States, don't write

948.53.text:
enough about the international aspects of
the companies that they cover.

953.36.text:
Google isn't alone of having a huge percentage
of their revenues and operations overseas.

960.12.text:
But people in the US, 'cause we're Americans,
we don't focus on that stuff more. But I knew

966.96.text:
I wanted to write about something international
and I chose China as an interesting case in

972.16.text:
point to focus on. And that turned out to
be a rich area, let's say.

980.51.text:
And I was able to tell that story. And so,
some of the things there were things that

984.44.text:
might surprise people. I think also, and I'd
done some of this for Wired, just knowing

990.62.text:
how Search and Ads work in a little more detail,
the level--. And Google I know has been trying

996.66.text:
to address this with videos and other things
and being a little more open.

1000.50.text:
There's probably no two words more offensive
to Google than "black box." I know those words

1007.76.text:
aren't popular around here. But so, maybe
to try to decode that a little, how those

1014.71.text:
things work, and try to explain it in lay
terms and add my explanations to the ones

1020.24.text:
that you folks have been doing, are sometimes
surprising.

1022.58.text:
People don't really get for instance, the
way Ads might work. The idea that there's

1028.44.text:
this auction that you bid on, but that the
high bid isn't always the winner. How good

1032.91.text:
the ad is actually fits into all that. And
to me, and to a lot of people, is totally

1037.75.text:
novel, even after all those years of--. How
old is that product now? Nine years old?

1042.78.text:
But it's worth explaining and getting into
because from that equation of AdWords, so

1049.11.text:
many things fall out. And in the space of
a book, I had time to really talk about how

1056.03.text:
those things all work together, where the
science in Search and the science in ads,

1059.80.text:
the science of AI, and the testing and the
data from users all come together because

1066.98.text:
there is this holistic thing going on here
that takes big arms to grasp and lots of pages.

1074.83.text:
>>FEMALE AUDIENCE MEMBER #2: Hi. Thanks for
being here. My question is about what--. One

1079.42.text:
of the things that I love about working here
is our culture. And I'm curious what really

1084.62.text:
struck you about our culture and what thoughts
you might have on us keeping that culture

1091.04.text:
and maintaining it going forward 'cause it's
a challenge we face?

1095.28.text:
>>Steven Levy: Right. Well, obviously I've
addressed the culture a lot and one of the

1099.45.text:
things, just talking about with George about
how he set up the offices and the roots of

1104.26.text:
that. Actually, he even went back to Susan
Wittgiske, who said that in the original Google

1109.60.text:
office, which was her house, one day, some
guy came to deliver a refrigerator to her

1116.28.text:
But Larry and Sergey just signed for it and
said, "Put it in here." They put it on the

1122.71.text: >>Ben Fried: Was that the first micro kitchen?

1125.97.text:
>>Steven Levy: Yes. Yeah. In a word and that
was the beginning of free food at Google.

1132.13.text: >>Ben Fried: Special thanks to Susan I guess.

1134.47.text:
>>Steven Levy: Yeah, yeah. Well, to her credit
she went with it and I think Google's been

1145.49.text:
And vice versa. But the parts of the culture--.
It's interesting 'cause when it was a small

1150.79.text:
company, of course, everyone spent time with
Larry and Sergey. And Google, to a large extent,

1160.63.text:
And as you get to a bigger company, it gets
tougher and tougher to do that. So that, the

1165.45.text:
question is how do you eventually do that?
I was at -- I spoke at a gathering of the

1172.17.text:
Geo Group. A couple times I've been asked
to talk to Google groups. And since Google's

1177.90.text:
talked to me so many times, I felt the least
I could do was agree to those requests there.

1183.50.text:
And someone asked me, "Well, what's Larry
really like?" And I thought, "What a weird

1187.21.text:
question. You work in the company there. I'm
just a journalist going in there." But of

1191.86.text:
course, when you're talking about a company
of 24,000 people, how many people really see

1197.49.text: and spend time with the executives there?

1201.54.text:
And especially where's that moment in time
a few years ago where Larry and Sergey dismissed

1206.20.text:
their assistants. Is this familiar to all
you? Yeah. It's a classic story where--. And

1212.67.text:
Larry explained this to me. He said, "Well
people have the ability to say yes to a meeting

1216.48.text:
and I didn't want that. Meetings are my least
favorite thing."

1220.40.text:
And they gave themselves the freedom to just
go around the company there. But of course,

1226.81.text:
people had to adjust to this because some
people really wanted to talk to Larry and

1230.71.text:
Sergey, or see them. And I compared it to--.
People would track them. I compared it to

1234.61.text:
people who, like the aircraft fanatics, who
track planes in airports and mark down the

1243.66.text:
People took note of Larry and Sergey sightings
and figured out strategies to stalk them.

1250.59.text:
And I tell the story of one guy who came out
from Zurich 'cause he really wanted to hear

1255.09.text:
from Larry about the fate of his project,
whether Larry had an idea of it. And he came

1259.42.text:
from Zurich and went to a TGIF and actually
talked first, talked to Sergey who said, "You

1265.49.text:
have to talk to Larry." And went to Larry
in his office there and had a conversation

1269.94.text:
So, channeling those is a challenge that actually,
I think, people at Google--tell me otherwise

1276.41.text:
if it's not true--have a pretty good sense
of how they think. Ben?

1281.37.text:
>>Ben Fried: I may get more access to Larry
and Sergey than the average Googler. Although,

1287.29.text: I'm not so sure of that, but I might. But--

1292.51.text:
I think they're very open about that. Right?
They're singularly open about what's on their

1296.48.text:
mind and how they approach the problem. And
they don't just say what they want, but they

1300.15.text: say why they want it and what led to that.

1302.63.text:
>>Steven Levy: Right. Right. But it's like
the values of like scale and speed and ambition,

1308.24.text:
>>Steven Levy: just core to them, I think
do get channeled throughout the company. So

1310.94.text:
that's interesting. Another aspect of the
culture that I found really interesting was

1315.11.text:
the hiring practices. And I can't tell you
how many people I talked to who were in their

1321.23.text:
middle ages, who were just flabbergasted when
they applied for jobs at Google and had to

1326.48.text: come up with their SAT scores, and their GPAs--

1331.58.text:
And actually, this is kind of interesting
because Google's very, as you know, very data-oriented.

1337.32.text:
And I talked to Stacie Sullivan, the head
of HR. And she said really in the studies

1342.14.text:
that they've done, they can't really prove
the correlation between a super-high SAT score

1349.50.text:
and a successful Google employee. Yet that's
something that remains important from what

1356.59.text:
I mean, I also was surprised that Larry signs
off on every single employee, which is amazing

1361.82.text:
to me. I mean, he explained how he did the
science of how that works, where he--. He

1367.28.text:
has a sort of like compressed version of the
recruitment package, the hiring package, whatever

1371.55.text:
it's called. And he's able to go through it
very quickly, but his eyeballs rest on the

1378.13.text:
recommendation to hire every single person,
which is remarkable.

1382.15.text:
>>MALE AUDIENCE MEMBER #3: So I've had a chance
to read the book. I really enjoyed it, so

1387.25.text: >>Steven Levy: Are you a fast reader?

1388.25.text:
>>MALE AUDIENCE MEMBER #3: A good bit. What
didn't make it into the book, besides all

1393.51.text:
the confidential stuff? You chose specific
chapters and specific topics. But what else

1399.46.text: would you have wanted to publish?

1401.30.text:
>>Steven Levy: Hmm. Well there was quite a
lot, really. I mean, actually one thing that

1405.87.text:
I spent a little time on that wound up only
a couple paragraphs on, was some of the issues

1413.52.text:
of Google design and interface, which I think
is really interesting.

1418.50.text:
So I sort of compressed that discussion. I
really couldn't find a great place to go on

1422.39.text:
at length about it. But I find it fascinating
how Google has this design philosophy, which

1431.34.text:
in some areas gets criticism. And those were
from fairly well-publicized conflagrations

1439.28.text:
where designers went off in a huff saying,
"Google's not friendly to designers."

1445.62.text:
But I think I got a great explanation from
Margaret Stewart, who's now at YouTube, who

1451.81.text:
is a designer. And she used to work with Marissa.
And Marissa once explained that in saying

1456.47.text:
that, "Basically, we want Google to look like
it might have been designed by a machine."

1461.87.text:
Because what they wanna convey is that there's
no bias in there.

1466.03.text:
So core to Google is the idea that this search
engine is not being biased, that it's taking

1472.43.text:
the algorithms based on -- where success is
based on how they measure people are happy

1478.83.text:
in the searches. And the implicit message
then in design has to be well, there's no

1485.54.text:
some artist with a long moustache, Dali moustache,
who's making swoops and swooshes and things

1491.48.text: like that. But it's very clean and straightforward.

1494.95.text:
So, to me it's worthy of a longer discussion,
but it just didn't make the cut. [pause]

1503.69.text:
>>MALE AUDIENCE MEMBER #4: Hi. I can imagine
that you must have been winding up writing

1508.91.text:
the book when the WikiLeaks memos came out
about Google and China. I know there's a few

1513.63.text:
that were pertinent. I'm kinda interested
in your reaction to those. Like, did it, do

1516.79.text:
you feel it changed the story in any significant
way?

1518.79.text:
>>Steven Levy: Well actually, it confirmed
the story in a significant way. And you're

1523.20.text:
right. It was just around that time. And I
was frantically trying to get hold of more

1530.26.text:
of those memos that dealt with Google. If
you remember, there was a couple days where

1536.74.text:
the Times reported on some of it, but there
was a gap between when WikiLeaks actually,

1542.05.text:
where then the Times produced the content
of the memos themselves.

1548.36.text:
So, I was able to get those in. I don't even
know if there's more to come. But some of

1554.70.text:
the things actually did just confirm from
the State Department's point of view what

1560.48.text:
they were hearing from sources, stuff that
I had already nailed down in China there.

1566.38.text:
So fortunately, it wasn't anything contradictory
there. And also, since their stuff was sometimes

1572.19.text:
raw intelligence, it wasn't necessarily stuff
you could take to the bank. So, I had to be

1576.47.text:
careful there in what I put in there and how
I put it. [pause]

1580.72.text:
>>MALE AUDIENCE MEMBER #5: So, what are we
bad at and what are we doing wrong? And how

1588.06.text:
>>Steven Levy: That's a great question. Well,
I think that what I found has been a problem

1596.05.text:
in Google products is there's a lot of care
in thinking of products and putting them out.

1605.60.text:
And even though there is, the philosophy is
to get things out and keep working on it,

1612.56.text: but is to deliver, to stick with products.

1616.83.text:
So, you take something like Wave, which is
a really innovative product by a very innovative

1622.93.text:
team. And Google obviously clearly cared a
lot about it and it was the big star of the

1627.83.text:
IO show. But to me, this was the kind of product
that just would have difficulty finding its

1636.05.text:
place just on its own. And I did an interview
at the Churchill Club with Ray Ozzie, not

1646.08.text:
They did that amazing demo if you remember
that if you stuck with it for an hour and

1651.64.text: a half, you'd understand the product. And--

1657.07.text:
but and Ray thought it was, there was a lot
great in the product. He said the simplicity

1666.09.text:
is real important there and you have to work
through it. And it really was a product that

1670.63.text:
Notes, which Ray had designed, was a good
analog.

1674.59.text:
And when Notes came out, they did an incredible
amount of support. They would go into a company

1679.19.text:
and work with people. And this wasn't done
with Wave. And I asked Eric about this last

1686.56.text:
summer whether that might have been a case
where Google should've varied from its philosophy

1693.26.text: of putting things out. If it catches on, great.

1696.27.text:
Otherwise, failure's part of our business.
And he actually stuck to the guns. He said,

1703.31.text:
"No, no. This is the way we are. That's just
Google. We'll put out something and if it

1709.01.text:
doesn't catch on, OK. Failure's built in.
We built our data systems so the servers can

1715.98.text:
fail and we put out products knowing some
are ambitious and thy're gonna fail."

1721.77.text:
And I actually feel that it would do Google
well to put more effort into supporting--and

1729.43.text:
I know this may be a bad word--marketing products
like that.

1739.40.text:
So that's a point there. And of course, this
is gonna be interesting to see as Google gets

1745.85.text:
more into Social stuff, too, because I do
write about some of the missteps in Social.

1751.79.text:
And I think Orchid's another case where support
could've put Google in a better position there

1757.73.text:
though it was pointed out to me that to give
it the support necessary, when Google was

1762.37.text:
such a small company, you would've really
had to strip out a sizeable percentage from

1766.99.text:
other teams just to give it the engineers
it deserved, because a lot of the engineers

1770.96.text:
for Orchid were really concerned at that early
point of moving it from the dot net code base

1776.13.text: to what Google normally runs on.

1778.14.text: So, but that's one that I can identify. [pause]

1784.13.text:
>>Ben Fried: So, maybe while we're waiting
for another question, I had another question,

1789.10.text:
which is that I've talked to a lot of people
who started from outside Google and relatively

1794.98.text:
recently moved in. And it's interesting to
watch their opinions of the company change

1800.53.text:
after they acclimate to the culture and what
it's like to work here and learning what goes

1802.64.text:
on behind the development curtain or something
like that.

1805.58.text:
And did you have any experiences like that
where you observed that your opinion of the

1810.24.text:
company, or the products or people changed
as a result of the proximity that you got?

1813.98.text:
>>Steven Levy: Well, consider that my immersion
into Google began around June 2008 and comes

1824.13.text:
up to now. One of the changes in Google between
then and now and the changes in Google, the

1829.05.text:
perception of Google between then and now,
they're really significant. So that was an

1835.75.text:
But what I found is that anyone who goes to
Google, two years later,

1841.42.text:
>>Steve Levy: sees a different Google. Most
people, during Google's history, there was

1847.16.text:
sort of a plateau in hiring around late 2008,
2009, so it didn't, for a little period didn't

1854.36.text:
grow as quickly. And this year, of course,
it's gonna grow again. But if you went to

1859.55.text:
Google in 2002, two years later it was twice
the size, different company.

1863.29.text:
Same with 2004, right? So no matter when you
got in there, in two years you were like bemoaning

1870.54.text:
how big it's gotten, right? And then of course,
the people who were there in 2002, would say,

1876.28.text:
"What were you talking about? Remember then."
Right? So, and I think the big shift that

1883.56.text:
came with those years was really coping with
the perception of Google.

1888.11.text:
Then, it changed. At a certain point, people
saw the degree to which Google affected them,

1897.06.text:
that Google's competitors became super energized
and focused on spreading the message about

1904.63.text:
the possible dangers of Google. And I think
I've done a pretty good job of doing that.

1909.23.text:
And that also because of the belief from the
top down that you, at Google, are doing the

1919.27.text:
right thing, you're righteous folks, sometimes
you don't always appreciate the degree to

1926.14.text:
which other people are now worried about the
size and the degree of information about you.

1932.24.text:
And I think the classic example of that is
the repercussions from the Book Search thing,

1938.38.text:
where even though very smart people here,
intellectually, everyone understands how people

1946.70.text:
are reacting to it, but there was this--just
at the core--just a disbelief. Don't they

1951.28.text: get that the great thing we're doing for civilization?

1954.56.text:
How can they be objecting to this? And you
can see it in what Larry says and the Op Ed

1962.41.text: that Sergey wrote for the New York Times.

1964.84.text:
>>Steven Levy: I remember they had a press
conference, or a press round table, just right

1968.88.text:
across the street actually. Right across the
street there, on the day that Sergey did that.

1973.21.text:
And he was saying, "We're helping people.
Why are they attacking us?"

1976.63.text:
>>MALE AUDIENCE MEMBER #6: Hi. I was just
wondering if you could compare and contrast

1981.98.text:
Google with other large tech companies in
general and maybe things that Googlers might

1988.62.text:
not themselves be aware of, because we've
been customized to our surroundings.

1993.47.text:
>>Steven Levy: Well I guess the classic comparison
comes with Microsoft. So, in the 1990s, Microsoft

2002.59.text:
was seen as the company that ruled all, right?
And again, it was an engineering company run

2009.81.text:
by a very strong founder and -- that ran into
trouble because of its power.

2018.69.text:
Now, I covered Microsoft a lot during those
days. And I think there are -- while there

2024.45.text:
are strong similarities in this sense as I
mentioned, there are essential differences

2028.11.text:
there. I think there's a philosophically--.
Bill Gates and Larry and Sergey don't just

2033.93.text: resonate to the same tuning fork, let's say.

2039.71.text:
Google is more of a bottom up company that--.
Microsoft is very much--. The marching orders

2049.29.text:
come from above there and indeed, when product
managers typically come from Microsoft to

2059.57.text:
As a matter of fact, in I think it was 2001.
It was the inability of product managers from

2068.05.text:
places like Microsoft to fit in well into
Google that led Larry and Sergey to say, "We

2075.04.text:
gotta get rid of product managers entirely.
Get rid of this whole level there." Which

2079.19.text:
didn't really take and they came back. But
for a little while, like literally every engineer

2083.96.text:
was reporting to Wayne Rosing, the head of
engineering.

2087.33.text:
And this was a big debate that Larry felt
that people don't wanna be managed. And Bill

2092.46.text:
Campbell, who had just started to advise them,
said, "No, Larry. You're wrong. People do

2096.15.text:
wanna be managed." And they actually called
in people, one by one. It was about 8:00 at

2102.11.text:
night. A bunch of people still working there.
And they asked them, "Do you wanna be managed?

2108.22.text:
And people said yes, but Larry went ahead
and did it anyway.

2112.66.text:
But then, but because of the Microsoft kind
of people there. Now, as it turns out, it's

2119.04.text:
a big company. You need managers. And everyone
understands that now. But still, Google has

2128.39.text:
its own kind of culture with this bottom up
thing.

2132.19.text:
And I think also, just basically, if you look
at just the behavior of the companies in China

2136.87.text:
now, you see a difference now. I think, to
its credit, I think the ultimate outcome of

2141.86.text:
the China thing was something where the morality
of what was happening there did play a role

2149.26.text:
in that. And I think particularly, from Sergey's
very passionate stance that he took after

2158.48.text:
the break-in occurred there, and it was always
part of the equation there.

2162.86.text:
And I asked Steve Ballmer at a conference
a few months ago about his company's performance

2174.57.text:
in China. Because quite frankly, I was a little
surprised to see--. To me, it was sort of

2179.64.text:
an easy shot for them to say something supportive
about what Google did instead of just saying,

2186.33.text: "Well we followed the laws of China."

2187.99.text:
Which is basically what he said. And he answered
me with that, he'd say, "When I went to college,

2193.40.text:
there was this big debate about apartheid,
about whether companies should support South

2200.59.text:
Africa in hopes of changing the system from
within, or whether we should boycott." And

2209.10.text:
clearly, he was taking the side of saying,
"Well, we're gonna support that."

2214.60.text:
Which I thought was sort of interesting because
of this 2006 hearing in Congress, which was

2221.10.text:
something--you remember that? It was just
on the eve of Google's entry into China, with

2228.48.text:
DotSiam and the search engine that was censored.
And the hearing was led by a Congressman who

2237.10.text:
was the only Holocaust survivor ever to appear
in Congress.

2241.40.text:
And he took the people from Google, Yahoo,
Microsoft, and Cisco over the coals. Asked

2247.16.text:
each one--poor Elliot Schrage had to represent
Google--each one asking, "Are you ashamed?

2252.21.text:
Are you ashamed?" And the book invoked most
during that hearing was this book that had

2257.02.text:
come out about a year earlier called, "IBM
and The Holocaust."

2260.98.text:
And that was the analogy that people were
making there. So it seemed to me that Microsoft

2266.58.text:
might want to avoid phrases like, "We're just
following the laws of the country there."

2276.23.text:
>>Ben Fried: The Lieutenant Calley defense,
right?

2278.23.text:
>>Ben Fried: The Watergate defense, I guess
actually. I'll do it, I'll follow orders.

2279.23.text:
>>Steven Levy: So I think that – I sort
of lost the thread -- the differences between,

2286.00.text:
but I think that is different. And Google
now, it's a big company and there's this "don't

2293.35.text:
be evil" thing. I'm surprised we've gone this
far without having that mentioned. But and

2299.41.text:
it's used quite often as a bludgeon against
Google. Oh, if Google does this. You read

2303.68.text: about that Google uses tax break.

2306.06.text:
Well, don't be evil, huh? That comes all the
time. But, and I know that Cindy McCaffrey,

2311.47.text:
who was the original Head of Communications,
sort of rues the day that that came out into

2318.26.text:
the mainstream. She said, "I knew once that
got out, they were goooing to use it against

2323.93.text:
us there." But surprisingly, I find that in
talking to a lot of people at Google who'd

2329.64.text:
been there a long time, they don't regret
that.

2331.94.text:
They said they still find it useful. People
don't go around saying it necessarily, but

2337.14.text:
it is something that's built in there. So
I think in a positive sense, that's a difference.

2343.70.text:
That's one reason why I'm interested in the
company. That it actually tries, at least

2348.60.text:
to grapple with these issues. It's not always
as successful as it wants to be.

2354.01.text:
It doesn't always meet its standards, but
it's in the mix. And I think that's something

2363.15.text:
>>Ben Fried: So, on a slightly different note,
when David Fincher and Aaron Sorkin get ready

2372.85.text: to make the next great tech company movie--

2377.70.text: who should they cast for Larry and Sergey?

2385.56.text:
That's a good one. Actually, this point came
up before. And I don't know. Jake Gyllenhaal,

2394.29.text: would he make a good Larry?

2397.32.text:
>>Ben Fried: I think depending on the hair,
he could be Sergey. Little, little hair on

2401.07.text:
>>Steven Levy: Yeah, yeah. I don't know. I
guess we'd have to google that and figure

2404.78.text:
out--. Do the image search and figure out
all the good actors. I always thought that

2410.13.text:
what I would like to do is make an opera out
of the China experience.

2416.96.text:
>>Steven Levy: Yeah. Sergey, he went to China
early, but he never visited Beijing. They

2423.33.text:
started an office there. But I picture like
Steve Ballmer and Eric Schmidt, like pitching

2429.13.text:
And in the middle there's Kai-Fu Lee singing,
"I choose Google. I choose China." And it

2434.77.text:
could be a great scene there. So, if Phillip
Glass is listening, [laughter] here we go.

2440.74.text:
>>Ben Fried: [laughs] [pause] I really gotta
think about that.

2449.65.text:
That was deep. [Steven Levy laughs.] [pause]
What's the most interesting question you've

2457.44.text:
been asked about the book so far? How's that
for a meta-question?

2460.05.text:
>>Steven Levy: Yeah. Well, I guess people
wanna know how I got in there, right?

2466.57.text:
>>Steven Levy: That's a big question. And
whether Google was worried about what I do.

2473.33.text:
And I think what happened was there was a
certain period where I was sort of under the

2477.50.text:
radar. I mean, even though I was just there
so much that--.

2481.96.text:
And another thing that was really helpful
to me was the people on that APM trip. I don't

2486.27.text:
know if there are any here. I saw Prim upstairs
and I saw David Henry yesterday. But there's

2493.49.text:
some people on that trip who are here in New
York. They were sort of like a shadow network

2499.69.text:
for me. They weren't necessarily prominent
in the book, though one of them, Dan Siroker

2507.07.text:
actually, I wrote about after he left Google
and started to work for Obama for the campaign.

2512.92.text:
And I talk about how he used Google techniques
to power change.org. And -- but they fanned

2525.05.text:
out to all sorts of interesting places--Chrome
and Book Search, and Ads and other things.

2530.94.text:
And I would often just run into them somewhere
and we'd have a really good conversation.

2538.87.text: I'd learn what was happening there.

2541.47.text:
Not that there should be repercussions to
the people who are still there. Those aren't

2544.34.text: the ones who told me things. Hi, Craig.

2547.87.text:
>>MALE AUDIENCE MEMBER #7: Hi. So thanks first
for allowing us to indulge in the guilty pleasure

2552.47.text: of us asking you questions about us, but--

2554.47.text:
I gotta continue on the theme. There's a little
bit of a variation on a theme from an earlier

2557.82.text:
question, but I think we have a lot of internal
myths about what Google is like and what we

2561.50.text:
think Google is like. But you actually have
seen across a broader spectrum than most of

2567.51.text:
What do you think--. Are there things that
you've observed that don't really gibe with

2572.85.text:
our self-image? Things that we should know
that actually are not true about Google that

2579.80.text:
>>Steven Levy: Well, that's a good question.
We talked about some of those things. But

2585.31.text:
one, I think one thing that is interesting
is that--. So this is an engineering company,

2592.07.text:
but there's a lot of people who aren't engineers.
So it's interesting to talk about that divide

2596.52.text:
there. And we're in New York. I don't know
are there people who are Ad Sales people here?

2603.38.text:
Anyone? There you go. I actually wanted to
write about some of those 'cause there's an

2609.93.text:
element--. People, journalists again, don't
write very much about those people at Google

2617.10.text:
and clearly, they were important. And to me,
it was fascinating at the point. There was

2621.76.text:
this thing called "Premium Sunset" where the
– in AdWords took over all the ads.

2627.40.text:
It used to be that some of the ads were paid
by impression and not per click. And that

2632.07.text:
was a big transformation in the ad world in
general and the people working here. And I

2636.76.text:
talked about that. But also, there's – it's
sort of a class system at Google. The engineers

2642.96.text:
kinda rule. And this Jeff Levick, who used
to work here, once told me a story.

2650.03.text:
Early on in Google's history, where they had,
there weren't too many Ad people. They went

2656.49.text:
to Mountain View and they were met in some
little conference room in some budget hotel

2662.72.text:
in Mountain View. And Sergey came to the meeting.
And he spent the whole meeting futzing with

2668.56.text: the control panel of the AV thing.

2672.77.text: Basically trying to see how that worked. Right?

2676.19.text:
And Jeff told me, he said--pardon the language--"That
moment I realized that they don't care a rat's

2681.98.text:
ass about what we do here. That it's the engineers
here." Right? But of course, they do care.

2689.50.text:
They realize how important it is for these
people to explain to the clients exactly what's

2696.71.text: happening there and give them support.

2698.23.text:
It was a different kind of relationship there.
And I actually really enjoyed spending time

2704.11.text:
with them. And Tim Armstrong, actually, when
I interviewed him here promised me he would

2707.50.text:
take me on a sales call to General Motors.
And I was really looking forward to that.

2711.35.text:
But for reasons beyond anyone's control, he
never got to take me on that sales call there.

2718.61.text:
>>MALE AUDIENCE MEMBER #8: On the Book's Search
thread, it seems like we've reached the point

2724.07.text:
where there's a lot of skepticism or even
hostility out there in the real world, like

2730.37.text:
the head of the Harvard Library, Scott Turow
or somebody from the Author's Guild. What

2736.10.text:
do you think we could do to reassure the general
public that we're not trying to monetize a

2744.11.text:
lot of other people's IP, or in general, be
abusive?

2747.38.text:
Or is it just too late, that we're the Microsoft
of this decade and whatever we do must, because

2756.07.text:
>>MALE AUDIENCE MEMBER #8: because we have
deep ambitions, whatever we do must be evil?

2758.85.text:
>>Steven Levy: Well, that's a great question.
And I haven't done reporting post-Judge Chin's

2766.70.text:
decision of what Google actually is thinking
there. Clearly, people are sitting and trying

2774.39.text: to figure out the answer to that question.

2776.41.text:
What I would say--. And it's interesting you
mentioned the Harvard guy. Personally, I have

2781.43.text:
to say that as a writer and as an author,
I am excited to see all the world's books

2790.71.text:
in one corpus that I could search and get
that information, and know that something

2797.39.text:
is in a book and then maybe offering you the
chance to buy it, or if it's impossible, just--

2801.99.text:
knowing it's in there and giving you a chance
to find the book. And I don't mind if my book

2807.07.text:
is in there. And actually, I had a conversation
with the head of the Author's Guild, of which

2811.34.text:
I'm a member, about that. And but, Google,
I think, underestimated the degree of hostility

2822.35.text: it would take, that it was Google doing this.

2823.80.text:
And like you say, the well's been poisoned
to a certain degree. I think one, there's

2828.55.text:
a couple things that I would just suggest.
I don't know if the people making the decision

2836.40.text:
care about it, but I'd say that maybe instead
of saying that these books that we've scanned

2843.97.text:
are gonna remain only in our index, to say
anyone can index them, that we could give

2851.47.text:
Maybe if you license it. Even if you let,
would let Bing or wherever else license your

2859.51.text:
stuff, maybe that wouldn't be so threatening.
Personally, I thought that the greatest, the

2863.74.text:
greatest, -- the best thing to do would've
been to just fight the original claim on a

2868.66.text:
fair use thing. I thought that could've been
something of value for all of us to get the

2874.46.text:
fair use thing clarified on whether you could,
whether scanning a book was a fair use just

2881.55.text:
But right now, we're sort of in a position.
Everyone's sort of kicked it to Congress and

2887.68.text:
we all know how efficient a system that is
in getting legislation that fits what the

2893.20.text:
public need is. So, I imagine it is frustrating.
But I think that in order to do, get the log

2901.78.text:
jam out, Google's probably gonna have to make
some concession there and maybe by saying,

2907.62.text:
let's say even in theory, and it's easy for
me to say 'cause I didn't spend millions of

2913.06.text:
dollars scanning these books, but to say that's
available.

2917.62.text:
Look -- most people do their searching from
Google anyway, right? So, and that would be

2921.54.text:
sort of non-threatening. You spent the money
already. Right? So, talk is cheap, but mine's

2929.40.text: cheap, too. Except for this, of course.

2933.72.text:
>>Ben Fried: 12.99 on Google Books, available
as of yesterday, I might add.

2940.36.text:
>>Ben Fried: We've gotta get the pre-ordering
thing down still for that product.

2944.93.text:
>>Ben Fried: [ ] zoom. Did you have another
question?

2948.57.text:
>>MALE AUDIENCE MEMBER #9: You compared and
contrasted Google with Microsoft. I think

2956.26.text:
one thing that Larry and Sergey has never
said that I think Steve Jobs and Bill Gates

2957.93.text:
have both said is--to paraphrase somewhat—'That's
the stupidest f-ing idea I've ever heard.'

2965.73.text:
You talked a little bit about comparing Microsoft
with Google. How would you compare Apple with

2971.18.text:
>>Steven Levy: Both companies are dramatically
different. Ironically, there was a moment

2976.19.text:
in time when it looked like this would-- Apple
and Google were gonna be Humphrey Bogart and

2980.83.text:
Claude Rains, just marching off into the mist
of a beautiful friendship.

2986.61.text:
>>Steven Levy: Yeah. And but, that didn't
happen.

2990.80.text:
And Apple is a consumer electronics company,
essentially. It's very much focused on design--the

3000.61.text:
kind of design, which is an editorial statement.
And it's relentless in the kinds of things.

3007.92.text:
Maybe that's why they're complementary in
those kinds of things which would--.

3012.41.text:
Supporting the hardware, selling the hardware,
which Google has not shown strength in, traditionally.

3019.12.text:
On the other hand, Google understands the
internet, I think, even better than Apple.

3025.79.text:
Apple's done a pretty good job on the internet,
but--. So I think, and Google is--to the degree

3034.38.text:
that they're a bottom up--is a wild contrast
with a very much top down aspect of Apple.

3041.77.text:
And Apple, people are pretty much frozen until
they hear what's going on from the top there.

3047.74.text:
And fortunately, the have a person at the
top who's worth waiting for. His opinions

3052.54.text:
are pretty darn good. So, and just the feel
of the company is different. Someone, there

3058.31.text:
was a question on Quora that I answered because
someone I thought it was such an apt question

3065.70.text:
Someone said, "What's the difference between
the Google campus and the Apple campus?" And

3069.27.text:
both of them are lovely places, but Google
has sort of like a dorm feel to it. It's like

3076.92.text:
lots of interesting stuff around that you
have to look at, but it's kind of like messy

3082.25.text:
in a sense and there's all this stuff on whiteboards
when you look around you.

3086.10.text:
And Apple's so clean you could eat off the
floor, right? It's almost like their stores

3092.02.text:
and a product there. So, there's a whole lot
of signifiers of the difference between those

3099.15.text:
>>MALE AUDIENCE MEMBER #10: Hi. Thanks for
coming to talk with us. So, the earlier success

3104.10.text:
of Google as with all other companies is a
mix of luck and hard work and brilliance.

3108.71.text:
But I get the sense that Google's success
is due slightly less to luck than to other

3115.74.text:
For instance, I'm probably getting the details
wrong, but I believe Microsoft almost sold

3119.81.text:
DOS to IBM and didn't become a company. Whereas
you said, a couple different examples today,

3125.95.text:
Google did things very differently from getting
to hire a facilities manager. They tried to

3134.45.text:
So do you think there's any truth into that
statement that Google's success is less due

3137.61.text: to luck and more to planned success?

3139.00.text:
>>Steven Levy: Well, I mean any great company
is a mix I think of luck and those sorts of

3146.94.text:
skills. I could come back with you on Google
and say what if Yahoo or Excite, decided to

3154.66.text:
say yes to Larry and Sergey when they wanted
to sell the search engine to them early on?

3160.23.text:
Then there would not have been a Google, quite
literally.

3162.78.text:
So they got lucky that their product was too
good for the portals to want to adopt. There

3169.46.text:
was one meeting I talked about where they
showed it--

3171.73.text: >>Ben Fried: Coogle. Is this the Coogle conversation?

3173.61.text: >>Steven Levy: No, it was George Bell of Excite.

3177.53.text:
>>Steven Levy: They showed it to the head
of Excite, who was not an engineer at that

3183.03.text:
point. They brought in adult supervision at
Excite and there's this guy who came from

3191.05.text:
And he took a look at the search engine and
was appalled at how good it was. He said,

3195.52.text:
"I don't want people to come here and leave
right away. This is too good. We can't buy

3200.90.text: this." And he sent them home.

3206.00.text:
And it really was only when it became clear
that no one was gonna give them a million

3212.50.text:
dollars for their technology that they said,
"Well, we might as well start our own company

3218.71.text:
then." So that was a pretty lucky thing to
happen.

3221.39.text:
And clearly, it wasn't, Google didn't get
to where it is by just luck, but you need

3230.48.text: some luck along the way to be a big success.

3233.69.text:
>>MALE AUDIENCE MEMBER #11: So, what will
be Google's downfall? I mean, I think the

3242.27.text:
popular conception, at least outside Google,
maybe inside Google, is that Social is their

3247.13.text:
sort of blind spot. But maybe you can give
us your opinion on what you think the--.

3253.06.text:
>>Steven Levy: OK, so the way companies like
Google and Microsoft, that dominate in a certain

3257.99.text:
category. And they don't just go all at once.
They sort of fade away when you have a big

3263.89.text:
successful revenue model, like Microsoft has
with Windows and Office, and like Google has

3272.66.text:
But the question is are they gonna successfully
get past that innovator's dilemma and be able

3279.64.text:
to dominate in the next paradigm? I mean,
Google's done a pretty good job in one paradigm

3285.14.text:
of moving over to mobile. It was essential
that Google have a big mobile presence because

3291.80.text:
everyone knows at a certain point, maybe it's
even now. I'm not sure. I don't think so.

3297.23.text:
>>Ben Fried: On a mobile device rather than
desktops.

3299.16.text:
>>Steven Levy: On a mobile device. Has that
happened yet?

3301.54.text:
>>Ben Fried: I don't know if we've crossed
over, but if not, it's coming.

3303.15.text:
>>Steven Levy: Yeah, yeah, yeah. It will be
here if it isn't already. So, it's not like

3310.12.text:
Google has no plausible mobile strategy. We
all know it. But the Social thing is now becoming

3319.93.text:
that kind of thing. I think, and we see mobilization
here.

3323.95.text:
I think down the road, sometime in the next
ten years, there’s gonna be something big,

3329.35.text:
which I don't know what it is. Maybe someone
at Google knows what it is. But some other

3333.72.text:
big paradigm shift. It'll be the next thing,
whatever it is. And it'll need a bigger shift

3338.78.text:
than the shift to mobile, or the shift to
Social.

3342.59.text:
And that's really where--. That's gonna be
the test of whether Google is going to be

3347.84.text:
a company that coasts on its successes and
shows good results, but like Microsoft, doesn't

3354.40.text:
really have that excitement and the stock
plateaus and things like that. And I think

3361.41.text:
one thing, which indicates that Google might
have a shot, is that Larry and Sergey, they're

3370.75.text:
They're into thinking ahead. They're looking
to the future there. So to me, some people

3375.64.text:
criticize Google for things like the autonomous
cars, but I don't think that's crazy. I think

3383.44.text:
to me, first of all it's not really un-Googley.
These are cars with information processors

3390.48.text:
that rely in turn, that they gather information.
They get information from Google in order

3397.19.text:
It's AI. To me, it's very much in the spirit
of other Google stuff. But it's also an interesting

3401.75.text:
new area. Who knows what could come of that
in those cars gathering information about

3407.77.text:
the world there? So I think that taking these
moon shots just might be the way that Google

3416.37.text: takes the next big paradigm on.

3417.81.text:
>>Ben Fried: Thank you. Are we out of time
now? Is that--. So, that was a great note

3421.70.text: to end the conversation on. Thank you.

3423.70.text:
>>Ben Fried: That was upbeat and optimistic
and forward-looking.

3425.94.text:
[laughter]
You talked about our great strengths. So,

3428.18.text: Steven, thank you so much for coming.

3429.67.text:
>>Steven Levy: Thank you. I'll be signing
books, then?

3431.47.text: >>Ben Fried: Yeah. I think we have you--.

3432.47.text: >>Steven Levy: I'd be happy to do that, yeah.
